10/10

[i]Half-Life[/i] is a science-fiction masterpiece that deserves the immense love it receives from its adoring fans.

If you're like me, you've heard plenty of endless praise and love spread around this seemingly ethereal video game, but never actually bothered to play it. I had no reason not to do so, I just never really got around to it. On a whim about a week ago, I decided to play it late one night since I had just finished replaying another [i]Valve[/i] classic, [i]Portal[/i]. This is one of the best last-minute decisions I've made, although it did keep me up for hours on a work night, it was well worth the sleep deprivation. I was glued to the screen, the gameplay was so fluid and the world was so interesting, if it weren't for the dated graphics, I really wouldn't be able to find many things aside from nitpicks that would make me to rate it below any really quality titles coming out today. However, this game set the standard for plenty of these titles, and judging it in comparison to these acclaimed games today isn't very hard, as [i]Half-Life[/i] is very easy to pick up and fails to be much of a roadblock for people spoiled with modern video game technology. You are doing yourself a disservice by not at least trying this game out, as it has aged much better than a majority of old video game titles for sure.

The journey of [i]Gordon Freeman[/i] is a science-fiction spectacle to behold. As you journey through your now-destroyed research facility in hopes of smothering the alien invasion at hand, you will be presented with many puzzles and challenges that will test your skills and judgment. There are enthralling set-pieces here, and the length of this game is surprisingly longer than I anticipated, but it is an arguably perfect length, so it doesn't overstay its fantastic welcome, instead it knows exactly what it wants to do and keeps you entertained until the very end. The variety of aliens and other enemies you encounter keeps the many battles fresh and always presents a new challenge to the player, especially during boss segments, which even when their battles get obnoxious, it's still fascinating and a unique fight each time.

Overall, [i]Half-Life[/i] is a timeless masterpiece. There is really little to say about it that hasn't already been said. The classic label is earned here, whether you're talking about the creative set-pieces and environments or the nearly perfect gameplay that keeps one hypnotized for hours, it all accumulates into a must-play for anyone that's a fan of science fiction and first-person video games. It has me very excited to revisit [i]Gordon Freeman[/i] in the sequel, [i]Half-Life 2[/i]. If it's anywhere near the quality of its predecessor, then I am definitely in for a unforgettable, entertaining joyride.

[b][RATING: 9.5/10][/b]

This game had me engaged from beginning to end. While it definitely shows age and can be visually hard to look at when compared to how far the industry has come, it's still an incredible ride. With solid game design philosophy and super satisfying sound design, there's a lot to love about the game. 

As someone who hadn't played it until recently, I was expecting to feel lukewarm about it, especially due to how many "4K HD" games I've played in recent years, but to my surprise I almost spent an entire day of my free time going through and solving puzzles, strategically fighting headcrabs, and generally just fully immersing myself subconsciously into the role Gordon Freeman plays as the Joe Schmo with a theoretical physics PhD on their way to work. It scratches a science fiction itch regarding aliens that just vibes really well with me too. 

Definitely a more than worthwhile buy if not a must have, and if you do buy it then hey, catch me later, I'll buy you a beer.

Although this game is older than I am, the game seems to be well refined and well driven. The story and environment manage to come into one in a near flawless manner, with few complaints able to made on solid ground. Some of these complaints include how you have auto aim with every difficulty excluding hard mode, and how much damage the some enemies do even on medium. There are some "Funny moments" for lack of a better phrase. The puzzles also require for thought and learning your lesson a time or two, making you feel quite smart once you figure out the best way to pass them all.

All and all if you want to have a good experience with this game save frequently and be aware of your surroundings.

Купил Half-Life несколько дней назад. Игре уже вроде 20 лет, но начал проходить её только сейчас. Всегда хотел узнать, почему эта игра так обожаема, и понял почему. Необычные геймплэйные механики(для того времени) и довольно интересный сюжет, несмотря даже на довольно старую графику.Ставлю этой игре 9/10.

I appreciate older games but I just did not enjoy this one at all. The beginning was promising, but the unnecessary ice skatey platforming sections and marines that can instantly spot you, among a whole bunch of other gimmicky things, just made this a very frustrating game to play. It's true, the hype for this game made me expect a lot, but I didn't even get a game I would want to play again or recommend to anyone. I just can't think of an area of this game (i.e. story, gameplay, art style, etc) that rises above another game in the same era. Not sure at all where all the hype is from. Good thing is that this game is incredibly cheap, so I guess in a way I got my enjoyment for what I paid. If you want a good older game go get deus ex, goldeneye,  jedi knight, or another game.

Classic story-driven shooter that still feels good today. There is something about the gameplay, story, and programming that just blows my mind and simply hasn't been replicated.  The game also has a ton of little detailed features that you'd never know about, like how NPCs have a sense of smell with different reactions to different scents; that's way more advanced than it has any right to be.

If you haven't played it, this is the best gaming experience out there.  Also, remember to skip the Source port of the game.
